title: Revisiting Financial Sentiment Analysis: A Language Model Approach
author: Hamid Moradi-Kamali (Iran University of Science and Technology), Mohammad-Hossein Rajabi-Ghozlou (Iran University of Science and Technology), Mahdi Ghazavi (Iran University of Science and Technology), Ali Soltani (Iran University of Science and Technology), Amirreza Sattarzadeh (Iran University of Science and Technology), Reza Entezari-Maleki (Iran University of Science and Technology)
relevance_why: The paper proposes an innovative approach to sentiment analysis that could inform audio sentiment detection systems by integrating context, which is applicable in audio and speech fields.
background: This paper addresses the challenge of predicting short-term market movements based on social media sentiment, proposing a method that uses market-driven labeling.
contribution: This paper introduces a market-derived labeling approach to solve the problem of inaccurate traditional sentiment analysis, achieving improved prediction accuracy of short-term market trends.

technical_comparison.previous_methods: Traditional sentiment analysis methods often rely on human-annotated sentiment labels, which can be subjective and lead to inaccurate predictions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by using labels derived from actual market movements, allowing the model to learn more effectively about the implications of textual sentiment.

key_innovation: The approach utilizes market dynamics to derive sentiment labels, enhancing both the accuracy and relevancy of sentiment predictions for financial markets.
real_world_impact: The findings could enable more reliable trading strategies in the financial market, promoting better investment decisions based on real-time sentiment analysis.
limitations: The method assumes a direct relationship between tweet sentiment and market movement, which may overlook more complex factors influencing market behavior.

new_terms.Triple Barrier Labeling: **Triple Barrier Labeling** is a method that assesses financial trends by imposing upper and lower profit-taking and stop-loss thresholds along with a time limit to classify market movements.
